Project Number: 43062  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
November 2009 
 
 
 
People's Republic of Bangladesh: Capacity Building 
and Support to the Transport Sector Coordination 
Wing of the Planning Commission

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for capacity 
development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Transport  Sector  Coordination Wing  of  the 
Planning Commission. ADB approved the TA concept paper on 9 September 2009. In October 
2009, an ADB fact-finding mission held discussions with the Planning Commission and the 
Economic  Relations  Division  to  prepare  the  TA.  It  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
government on the TA impact, outcome, scope, implementation arrangements, and terms of 
reference.1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  transport  system  of  Bangladesh,  catering  to  domestic  and  international  traffic, 
comprises roads, railways, inland waterways, two seaports, maritime shipping, and civil aviation. 
Presently the country has about 271,000 kilometers (km) of roads, including about 21,000 km of 
major roads. It also has 2,706 route-km of railways; 3,800 km of perennial waterways, which 
increase to 6,000 km during the monsoon; the ports of Chittagong and Mongla; two international 
airports (Chittagong and Dhaka); and eight domestic airports. Major improvements have been 
made  for  roads;  ports,  especially  in  Chittagong;  and  civil  aviation.  The  length  of  railways 
remains  unchanged from  what  was  inherited of  the  British  Indian  Railway  system. It  is  a 
disjointed network separated by the Jamuna River with two separate and incompatible gauges. 
The length of navigable waterways has decreased from about 8,000 km in 1970 partly due to 
inadequate dredging. 
 
3.  Three transport-related ministries implement subsector investment plans and policies 
with their implementing agencies. The Ministry of Communication is responsible for railways 
through  Bangladesh  Railways  and  for  major  highways  through  the  Roads  and  Highway 
Department.  The  Ministry  of  Local  Government,  Rural  Development,  and  Cooperatives  is 
responsible for the rural road network through the Local Government Engineering Department. 
Urban roads are under city corporations. The Ministry of Shipping is responsible for inland 
waterways, ports, and shipping. Under the ministry, the Chittagong Port Authority manages the 
Chittagong  seaport  and  the  Mongla  Port  Authority  manages  the  Mongla  seaport;  the 
Bangladesh Inland Waters Transport Authority manages ports on inland water systems; and the 
Land  Port  Authority  manages  land  ports.  The  Planning  Commission  is  responsible  for 
coordinating investment planning and main policies. 
 
4.  The public sector provides most of the rail and port services. In recent years, however, 
private sector involvement has increased considerably in road and inland water transport and 
ocean shipping. It is also gradually entering the domestic air transport and passenger rail 
markets as well as transport logistics. Geography limits the inland waterway system. Many 
rivers do not have high-capacity bridges; reliance on ferries results in the use of small trucks for 
both intra-  and  interurban distribution  services.  Rail and  road  services are  constrained  by 
network capacity and poor quality of infrastructure. Inadequate maintenance has led to severe 
deterioration of even major road and rail sections. Cost recovery of all modes is low due to 
numerous regulations and subsidies. Asset replacement, in particular for railways, is infrequent 
and unplanned. Thus, service quality is low and unit costs of transport are high and rising. 
 
5.  Of the transport sector spending, which is the largest development expenditure in the 
country, most recent data indicates that roads received 80% of the transport budget, inland

2   
water transport 18%, and railways 2%. The funding allocated to roads was mostly used for 
major corridors and secondary roads. With very little expansion and renewal investment, railway 
and inland waterway infrastructure and services have degraded, resulting in decreased demand. 
From 1975 to 2005 the modal share of road transport rose from 54% to 88% for passenger 
traffic, and from 35% to 80% for freight; while the overall annual traffic growth rate in the past 10 
years has been nearly 8.2% for freight transport and 8.4% for passenger transport. 
 
6.  The government approved the National Land Transport Policy (NLTP) in April 2004. The 
policy introduced the concept of long-term network planning and integration of transport policy, 
planning, and appraisal across land transport modes. Based on the NLTP, the draft integrated 
multimodal transport policy emphasizes more rational and balanced investments, and better 
coordination across transport modes. Under the NLTP, the Transport Sector Coordination Wing 
(TSCW) was established in 2004 within the Planning Commission to coordinate with ministries 
such as communications, shipping, civil aviation, and tourism; and local government division, in 
relation  to  their  activities  for  long-term  planning,  investment  analysis,  monitoring  and 
coordination of policy implementation, and transport studies. 
 
7.  Each subsector undertakes physical and institutional improvements in line with a long-
term policy provided in the NLTP together with subsector master plans. Major subsector issues 
include (i) maintenance financing, quality, safety, and overloading of major roads; (ii) better 
planning in rural roads; (iii) restructuring of Bangladesh Railways into a commercially oriented 
organization  in  conjunction  with  substantial  investment  in  infrastructure,  rolling  stock  and 
wagons, equipment, and technical modernization; (iv) efficient dredging and tariff regulation for 
inland waterways; and (v) operating efficiency improvements in ports. As indicated in the NLTP, 
environmental consideration is needed in project assessment to help mitigate climate change. 
The road master plan is complete. The railway program for institutional reform is ongoing under 
the framework of the ADB Railway Sector Investment Program2 in parallel with the government 
railway development plan containing investment proposals for the next 20 years. The Inland 
Waterway Transport Sector Policy has been approved in principle and work on the master plan 
is being finalized. Operating efficiency of the Chittagong Port has improved through ADB loan 
and  TA  to  enhance  physical  and  institutional  elements.  Another  TA  is  currently  under 
preparation to develop an overall framework for port and logistics efficiency improvement in the 
country.   
 
8.  While solving constraints by mode, an optimal multimodal mix needs to be pursued at 
the  same  time  to  ensure  efficiency  of  economic  activities  and  energy  consumption,  with 
environmental  considerations  and  resource  constraints.  For  the  long  term,  the  optimal 
multimodal mix should help mitigate climate change. Inadequate coordination among transport 
subsectors  and  intermodal  connectivity  are  among  the  principal  issues  constraining 
improvement in mobility, accessibility, safety, service reliability, and productivity; as well as 
efficient investment to the transport sector.  
 
9.  The government needs a system for coordinating development plans, projects, and 
budgets  under  the  current  institutional  framework  so  that  it  can  prioritize  investments  by 
allocating limited resources among subsectors to maximize development impacts of the overall 
transport  sector  investment.  Support  to  coordination  among  transport  subsectors  is  a  key 
                                                
2  ADB. 2006. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche 
Financing Facility and Technical Assistance Grant to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Railway Sector 
Investment Program. Manila.

3 
development issue identified in the Bangladesh country strategy and program (2006–2010).3 
The  Department  for  International  Development  of  the  Government  of  the  United  Kingdom 
supported establishment and initial institutional strengthening of TSCW from 2004 to 2008 to 
improve quality of project reports for Planning Commission consideration and support long-term 
planning for railways, roads, inland waterways, and multimodal policy. TSCW is assessed to 
require capacity building support to ensure its functions are sustainable. This includes specialist 
services, especially for transport planning and project evaluation for multimodal considerations. 
Capacity development is also required for sustainable implementation and monitoring of long-
term plans, especially for the draft integrated multimodal transport policy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  efficiency  and  effectiveness  in  transport 
infrastructure investment through multimodal coordination and long-term project planning. This 
will enhance Bangladesh’s competitiveness in export and import markets through increased 
productivity of transport systems. 
 
11.  The TA will enhance TSCW capacity for interministerial and agency coordination and 
long-term integrated development of the transport sector. It will improve the quality of transport 
investment proposals including incorporation of long-term and multimodal aspects in project 
development  and  reduce  time  spent  by  the  Planning  Commission  considering  transport 
investment proposals. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will deliver (i) systems linking long-term plans to project development from the 
perspective  of  long-term  and  multimodal  planning,  and  (ii)  enhanced  project  appraisal 
frameworks in selected subsectors. The TA’s fundamental methodology is to facilitate transport 
sector planning using a multimodal coordination perspective by enhancing the knowledge and 
skills of TSCW. The TA will enhance TSCW capacity through technical advice and on-the-job 
training  in  developing  and  implementing  (i)  a  coordination  mechanism  among  subsector 
ministries  and  agencies,  (ii)  long-term  planning  and  implementation  monitoring  in  each 
subsector, and (iii) improved investment analysis and associated technical studies including 
development of a geographic information system database. 
 
(i)  On-the-job training. The TA-financed consultant will help TSCW with planning and 
coordination  activities  through  on-the-job  training  and  advice  on  (a)  developing 
coordination procedures and mechanisms among subsector ministries and agencies, 
(b)  implementing  transport  policy,  (c)  developing  systems  for  monitoring  policy 
implementation,  (d)  reviewing  and  updating  master  plans  as  required,  and  
(e) enhancing project appraisal frameworks. 
 
(ii)  Workshops and training. To sustain the capacity building efforts, workshops and 
training will be organized. Interministerial workshops will facilitate the exchange of 
information and experience among various government officials. International best 
practices  and  their  effective  application  in  local  contexts  can  be  shared  and 
developed. Short-term international training will be explored as required. 
                                                
3  ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program: Bangladesh, 2006–2010. Manila.

4   
 
(iii)  Surveys. The consultant will undertake the required surveys in coordination with 
relevant ministries and agencies, especially those requiring improved techniques and 
skills.  This  may  include  assessment  of  traffic  and  capacity,  and  methods  of 
measuring key performance indicators. The consultant may prepare a brief manual 
of such surveys and methods so that TSCW will be able to undertake surveys and 
assessment in the future. Initially, the simplest and most suitable methods will be 
recommended to TSCW for undertaking such surveys with optimal use of resources. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $625,000 equivalent; ADB will provide 
$500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government’s counterpart in-kind contribution will be $125,000 
equivalent  in the  form of  office  accommodation, support  facilities,  counterpart  staff,  maps, 
reports, and other logistical support. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Planning Division of the Ministry of Planning will be the executing agency and 
TSCW  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  The  Planning  Division  will  facilitate  senior 
interministerial coordination, secure the budget, and monitor the delivery and expenditure of the 
TA.  The  head  of  TSCW,  the  implementing  agency,  will  be  appointed  project  director  to 
supervise  day-to-day  TA  activities,  and  report  to  the  Planning  Division  and  the  steering 
committee. A steering committee, chaired by the member, Physical Infrastructure Division, of 
the Planning Commission, with representation from subsector ministries and agencies, will be 
established  to  provide  overall  guidance  on  TA  delivery.  To  ensure  quality  delivery  to  the 
satisfaction of the Planning Commission, specific details of deliverables include (i) guidelines 
and  manuals  for  coordination  procedures  and  mechanisms,  and  policy  implementation;  
(ii) monitoring systems; and (iii) enhanced project appraisal frameworks in selected subsectors.  
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, beginning in March 2010 and ending in 
March 2011. It will be carried out by a firm of consultants comprising experts in transport 
planning, transport policy and institutions, transport economics, traffic engineering and modeling, 
and geographic information systems. About 8 person-months of international consulting and 
about  40  person-months  of  national  consulting  will  be  provided.  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time) using quality- and cost-based selection. The assignment involves senior 
policy discussions with many agencies, requiring innovation in project delivery. The simplified 
technical proposal will be used, with the weight of technical proposals at 90%. The outline terms 
of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. All equipment for the TA will be procured 
according  to  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and 
transferred to the government upon TA completion. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with the ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4  (January 2008, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
16.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  engagement, 
elaborating  the  initial  work  program  after  consultation  with  TSCW  and  ADB;  (ii)  monthly 
progress  reports  and  working  papers  as  required  for  each  project  assigned,  providing  a 
                                                
4  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

5 
summary  of  activities,  an  assessment  of  capacity-related issues,  and  recommendations  to 
enhance capacity; (iii) quarterly reports specifying achievements, issues, and further actions;  
(iv) a draft final report 1.5 months before TA completion, summarizing all activities undertaken, 
assessing in detail capacity enhancement, and recommending how capacity can be enhanced; 
and (v) a final report on TA completion, incorporating comments by the government and ADB.  
 
17.  Three nationwide workshops will be conducted  during TA  implementation. The first 
workshop  will  introduce  the  TA  to  involve  relevant  ministries  and  agencies.  The  second 
workshop, which will take place about 9 months after TA commencement, will discuss actions 
required for the remaining period of TA implementation and future requirements after the TA. 
The third workshop will provide achievements of the TA and identify requirements for additional 
capacity development. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for Capacity Building and Support to the Transport Sector 
Coordination Wing of the Planning Commission, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  The consultants will assist the Transport Sector Coordination Wing (TSCW) in ensuring 
implementation  of long-term plans  and consideration  of integrated multimodal transport for 
planning,  monitoring,  and  project  preparation.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  has  two 
components: (i) promotion of multimodal transport systems in the country, and (ii) enhancement 
of project appraisal frameworks. 
 
2.  The consultants will undertake the services in close consultation with TSCW. They will 
also  conduct  training  and  workshops  as  required,  and  interministerial  consultation  to 
disseminate the concept of integrated multimodal transport systems.  
 
  1.  Promotion of Multimodal Transport Systems  
 
3.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Identify  the  need  and  bottlenecks  for  implementing  integrated  multimodal 
transportation systems. 
(ii)  Develop and/or enhance systems linking long-term plans to project development. 
(iii)  Recommend  institutional arrangements  and capacity  building for multiagency 
coordination. 
 
a.  Assessment of Integrated Multimodal Transport Systems 
 
4.  The consultants’ tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Review and assess existing long-term plans for each subsector and the draft 
integrated multimodal transport policy. 
(ii)  Identify weak physical links and/or locations in the mode-based network and 
intermodal connectivity, e.g., port–railway, port–road, road–rail, based on existing 
studies and data, and supplementary studies as required. 
(iii)  Quantify increased use of infrastructure for each mode as a result of improving 
multimodal transport systems, and assess to what degree the modal mix balance 
has improved. 
(iv)  Identify  institutional  barriers  hindering  integration  of  transport  networks:  
(a)  pricing  and  financing,  (b)  energy  and  environment,  (c)  private  sector 
participation, (d) regulatory framework, (e) organization, and (f) database. 
 
    b.  Systems Linking Long-Term Plans to Project Development 
 
5.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  Identify and/or enhance key performance indicators for each transport subsector. 
(ii)  Identify the needs and architecture of the geographic information system (GIS) 
data base, traffic analysis, and project evaluation for identifying investment needs 
and/or gaps and measuring subsector key performance indicators and overall 
transport costs, from the perspective of long-term and multimodal planning.

10  Appendix 3 
 
(iii)  Assist line ministries and agencies in preparing annual development plans and 
annual  revenue  budgets  in  line  with  long-term  plans  and  multimodal 
considerations. 
(iv)  Develop manuals for these activities to be institutionalized, including a periodic 
data collection and/or update program. 
 
    c.  Institutional Arrangement for Multiagency Coordination 
 
6.  The consultants will have the following responsibilities:  
 
(i)  Assess constraints and opportunities of multiagency coordination. 
(ii)  Develop an optimal mechanism for efficient multiagency coordination. 
(iii)  Recommend institutional arrangements and requirements. 
(iv)  Develop guidelines and manuals with policy implementation monitoring targets. 
(v)  Set  up  baseline  data  of  the  existing  capacity  of  TSCW  and  measure  the 
improvement in a quantifiable manner in line with target measures provided in 
the  design  and  monitoring  framework.  Consultants  may  propose  other 
quantifiable measures as required. 
(vi)  Recommend capacity building needs for multimodal considerations. 
 
  2.  Enhancement of Project Appraisal Frameworks in Selected Subsectors 
 
7.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  Review existing practices of project preparation and appraisal by line ministries 
and the Planning Commission. 
(ii)  Assess project appraisal frameworks, including issues for their application by 
government officials. 
(iii)  Identify  focus  subsectors  to  be  enhanced  during  project  preparation  and 
appraisal. 
(iv)  Identify areas to strengthen the frameworks. 
(v)  Refine the frameworks in the selected subsectors. 
(vi)  Recommend a training program for government officials using the frameworks. 
 
B.  Required Expertise 
 
8.  The TA will be implemented for 12 months from March 2010 to March 2011. A team of 
consultants, both international and national, will be engaged with expertise in transport planning, 
transport policy and institutions, transport economics, traffic engineering and modeling, and GIS. 
The inputs will be 8 person-months of an international consultant as team leader (transport 
planning and policy), and 40 person-months of national consultants (10 for deputy team leader 
and policy advisor, 10 for transport planner, 4 for transport economist, 10 for GIS expert, and  
6 for traffic engineer and modeler). 
 
9.  The consultant  will engage  support staff required for  project  delivery including GIS 
assistant, systems assistant, computer assistant, office manager, messengers, and others as 
required. 
 
10.  For continuity, the consultant may engage other administrative staff engaged under 
previous  support  provided  by  the  Department  for  International  Development  of  the  United 
Kingdom.

Appendix 3  11 
C.  Deliverables 
 
11.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  engagement, 
elaborating  the  initial  work  program  after  consultation  with  TSCW  and  ADB;  (ii)  monthly 
progress  reports  and  working  papers  as  required  for  each  project  assigned,  providing  a 
summary  of  activities,  an  assessment  of  capacity-related issues,  and  recommendations  to 
enhance capacity; (iii) quarterly reports specifying achievements, issues, and further actions;  
(iv) a draft final report 1.5 months before TA completion, summarizing all activities undertaken, 
assessing in detail capacity enhancement, and recommending how capacity can be enhanced; 
and (v) a final report on TA completion, incorporating comments by the government and ADB.  
 
12.  Three nationwide workshops will be conducted  during TA  implementation. The first 
workshop will introduce the TA for relevant ministries and agencies. The second workshop, 
occurring  about  9  months  after  TA  commencement,  will  discuss  actions  required  for  the 
remaining period of TA implementation and requirements after the TA. The third workshop will 
provide achievements of the TA and identify requirements for additional capacity development.
